						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Japan</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Nippon" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Japan_(disambiguation)" title="Japan (disambiguation)">Japan (disambiguation)</a>&#32;and <a href="/wiki/Nippon_(disambiguation)" title="Nippon (disambiguation)">Nippon (disambiguation)</a>.</div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>

       </tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Contains_Japanese_text&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Contains Japanese text (page does not exist)">Template:Contains Japanese text</a>
</p><p><b>Japan</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-ja&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-ja (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-ja</a> <i><b>Nippon</b></i> or <i><b>Nihon</b></i>; formally <span lang="ja">日本国</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> <span class="unicode haudio" style="white-space:nowrap;"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/File:Loudspeaker.svg" title="File:Loudspeaker.svg">About this sound</a>&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:Upload&amp;wpDestFile=Ja-nippon_nihonkoku.ogg" class="new" title="Ja-nippon nihonkoku.ogg"><i><b>Nippon-koku</b></i></a></span></span> or <i><b>Nihon-koku</b></i>, literally "the State of Japan") is an <a href="/wiki/Island_country" title="Island country">island nation</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia (page does not exist)">East Asia</a>. Located in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, it lies to the east of the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, stretching from the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> in the south. The <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">characters</a> that make up Japan's name mean "sun-origin", which is why the country is sometimes referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Names_of_Japan" title="Names of Japan">Land of the Rising Sun</a>". Japan is an <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Japan" title="List of islands of Japan">6,852 islands</a>, the four largest being <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">Honshu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyushu" title="Kyushu">Kyushu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">Shikoku</a>. Together, these four islands hold about 97 percent of the country's land area. Japan has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">tenth-largest population</a>, with more than 126&#160;million people. Honshū's <a href="/wiki/Greater_Tokyo_Area" title="Greater Tokyo Area">Greater Tokyo Area</a> includes the <a href="/wiki/Capital_of_Japan" title="Capital of Japan"><i>de facto</i> capital city</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> and several surrounding <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan" title="Prefectures of Japan">prefectures</a>. It is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World%27s_largest_cities&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World's largest cities (page does not exist)">largest metropolitan area</a> in the world, with more than 30 million residents.
</p><p>Archaeological research indicates that people lived in Japan as early as the <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> period. The first written mention of Japan is found in <a href="/wiki/History_of_China" title="History of China">Chinese texts</a> from the 1st century&#160;AD. Influence from other nations followed by long periods of isolation has characterized <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of Japan (page does not exist)">Japan's history</a>. Japan evolved into a cohesive society during the <a href="/wiki/Heian_period" title="Heian period">Heian period</a> (8th-11th centuries AD). From the 12th century until 1868, Japan was ruled by successive feudal military dictatorships or shogunates in the name of the Emperor. In the early 17th century, Japan entered into a long period of isolation, which was only ended in 1853 when a United States fleet pressured Japan to open to the West. Nearly two decades of internal conflict and insurrection followed before the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emperor_Meiji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emperor Meiji (page does not exist)">Meiji Emperor</a> was restored as head of state in 1868 and the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> was proclaimed, with the Emperor enshrined as a divine symbol of the nation.
</p><p>Periodic insurrections and civil disturbances continued into the 1880s. A modern constitution was promulgated in 1889 and a Western-style <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diet_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diet of Japan (page does not exist)">parliament</a> established. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, victories in the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a> allowed Japan to expand its empire during a period of increasing militarism. From 1931, military expansion into China and Manchuria led to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> in 1937. Japan allied itself with the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a> in 1940, and the war in China became part of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> in 1941. While Japan initially enjoyed a period of military dominance, successive military defeats and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (page does not exist)">atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki</a> led to the end of the war in 1945, Japan's surrender and the loss of its empire. Under Allied military occupation lasting until 1952, Japan dissolved and restructured its military, adopted a revised <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">constitution</a> in 1947 and became a unitary <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> with an <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">emperor</a> and a democratically elected legislature.
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">major economic power</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> Japan has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">third-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fourth-largest economy</a> by purchasing power parity. It is also the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_exports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by exports (page does not exist)">fourth-largest exporter</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_imports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by imports (page does not exist)">fourth-largest importer</a>. Although Japan has officially <a href="/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution" title="Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution">renounced its right to declare war</a>, it maintains a modern military with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by military expenditures (page does not exist)">fifth largest military budget</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> used for self-defense and peacekeeping roles. According to Japan's health ministry, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_women&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese women (page does not exist)">Japanese women</a> have the second highest <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> of any country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, Japan also has the third lowest <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate.<sup id="cite_ref-haaretz.com_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-haaretz.com-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Table_A.17_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Table_A.17-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The English word <i>Japan</i> derives from the Chinese pronunciation of the Japanese name, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo2 (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo2</a> , which in Japanese is pronounced <i>Nippon</i> <span class="unicode haudio" style="white-space:nowrap;"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/File:Loudspeaker.svg" title="File:Loudspeaker.svg">About this sound</a>&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:Upload&amp;wpDestFile=Ja-nippon(%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC).ogg" class="new" title="Ja-nippon(日本).ogg">listen</a></span>&#160;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_help" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>·<a href="/w/index.php?title=File:Ja-nippon(%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC).ogg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="File:Ja-nippon(日本).ogg (page does not exist)"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span> or <i>Nihon</i> <span class="unicode haudio" style="white-space:nowrap;"><span class="fn"><a href="/wiki/File:Loudspeaker.svg" title="File:Loudspeaker.svg">About this sound</a>&#160;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:Upload&amp;wpDestFile=Ja-nihon(%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC).ogg" class="new" title="Ja-nihon(日本).ogg">listen</a></span>&#160;<small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">(<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_help" class="extiw" title="wikipedia:Media help"><span style="cursor:help;">help</span></a>·<a href="/w/index.php?title=File:Ja-nihon(%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC).ogg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="File:Ja-nihon(日本).ogg (page does not exist)"><span style="cursor:help;">info</span></a>)</small></span>. The pronunciation <i>Nippon</i> is more formal, and is in Japanese used for most official purposes, including international sporting events.
</p><p>From the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meiji_Restoration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meiji Restoration (page does not exist)">Meiji Restoration</a> until the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the full title of Japan was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>, meaning "the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Great Japan</a>". Today the name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a> is used as a formal modern-day equivalent; countries like Japan whose long form does not contain a descriptive designation are generally given a name appended by the character <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>, meaning "country", "nation" or "state".
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese people</a> refer to themselves as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a> and to their language as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>. Both <i>Nippon</i> and <i>Nihon</i> mean "sun-origin" and are often translated as <i>Land of the Rising Sun</i>. This nomenclature comes from <a href="/wiki/Japanese_missions_to_Imperial_China" title="Japanese missions to Imperial China">Japanese missions to Imperial China</a> and refers to Japan's eastward position relative to China. Before <i>Nihon</i> came into official use, Japan was known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English word for Japan came to the West via <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanban_trade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanban trade (page does not exist)">early trade routes</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Mandarin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Mandarin (page does not exist)">Old Mandarin</a> or possibly early <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">Wu Chinese</a> (吳語) pronunciation of Japan was recorded by <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">Marco Polo</a> as <i>Cipangu</i>. In modern <a href="/wiki/Shanghainese" title="Shanghainese">Shanghainese</a>, a Wu dialect, the pronunciation of characters <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo2 (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo2</a> 'Japan' is <i>Zeppen</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-wuu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-wuu (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-wuu</a>. The old <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">Malay</a> word for Japan, <i>Jepang</i>, was borrowed from a southern coastal Chinese dialect, probably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hokkien&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hokkien (page does not exist)">Fukienese</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ningbo_dialect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ningbo dialect (page does not exist)">Ningpo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> and this Malay word was encountered by <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> traders in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Portuguese_Malacca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Portuguese Malacca (page does not exist)">Malacca</a> in the 16th century. Portuguese traders were the first to bring the word to Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> An early record of the word in English is in a 1565 letter, spelled <i>Giapan</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_ancient_history">Prehistory and ancient history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Horyu-ji11s3200.jpg" title="File:Horyu-ji11s3200.jpg">File:Horyu-ji11s3200.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_Hall_(Japanese_Buddhism)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main Hall (Japanese Buddhism) (page does not exist)">Golden Hall</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=T%C5%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tō (page does not exist)">five-storey pagoda</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=H%C5%8Dry%C5%AB-ji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hōryū-ji (page does not exist)">Hōryū-ji</a>, among the oldest wooden buildings in the world, <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" title="National Treasures of Japan">National Treasures</a>, and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Japan (page does not exist)">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a></div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Paleolithic" title="Japanese Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> culture around 30,000&#160;BC constitutes the first known habitation of the Japanese archipelago. This was followed from around 14,000&#160;BC (the start of the <a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Dmon_period" title="Jōmon period">Jōmon period</a>) by a <a href="/wiki/Mesolithic" title="Mesolithic">Mesolithic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> semi-sedentary <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherer</a> culture, who include ancestors of both the contemporary <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">Ainu people</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yamato_people" title="Yamato people">Yamato people</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> characterized by pit dwelling and rudimentary agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Decorated clay vessels from this period are some of the oldest surviving examples of pottery in the world. Around 300 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Yayoi_period#Origin_of_the_Yayoi_people" title="Yayoi period">Yayoi people</a> began to enter the Japanese islands, intermingling with the Jōmon.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Yayoi_period" title="Yayoi period">Yayoi period</a>, starting around 500&#160;BC, saw the introduction of practices like wet-<a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> farming,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> a new style of pottery,<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Metallurgy" title="Metallurgy">metallurgy</a>, introduced from China and Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan first appears in written history in the Chinese <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Han" title="Book of Han">Book of Han</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Records_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Records of the Three Kingdoms">Records of the Three Kingdoms</a></i>, the most powerful kingdom on the archipelago during the 3rd century was called <a href="/wiki/Yamatai" title="Yamatai">Yamataikoku</a>. Buddhism was first introduced to Japan from <a href="/wiki/Baekje" title="Baekje">Baekje</a> of <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>, but the subsequent development of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japanese Buddhism</a> was primarily influenced by China.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Despite early resistance, Buddhism was promoted by the ruling class and gained widespread acceptance beginning in the <a href="/wiki/Asuka_period" title="Asuka period">Asuka period</a> (592–710).<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nara_period" title="Nara period">Nara period</a> (710–784) of the 8th century marked the emergence of a strong Japanese state, centered on an imperial court in <a href="/wiki/Heij%C5%8D_Palace" title="Heijō Palace">Heijō-kyō</a> (modern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nara,_Nara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nara, Nara (page does not exist)">Nara</a>). The Nara period is characterized by the appearance of a nascent <a href="/wiki/Japanese_literature" title="Japanese literature">literature</a> as well as the development of Buddhist-inspired art and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historic_Monuments_of_Ancient_Nara&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara (page does not exist)">architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smallpox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smallpox (page does not exist)">smallpox</a> epidemic of 735–737 is believed to have killed as much as one-third of Japan's population.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> In 784, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emperor_Kammu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emperor Kammu (page does not exist)">Emperor Kammu</a> moved the capital from Nara to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nagaoka-ky%C5%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nagaoka-kyō (page does not exist)">Nagaoka-kyō</a> before relocating it to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heian-ky%C5%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heian-kyō (page does not exist)">Heian-kyō</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Kyoto" title="Kyoto">Kyoto</a>) in 794.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:M%C5%8Dko_Sh%C5%ABrai_Ekotoba_2.jpg" title="File:Mōko Shūrai Ekotoba 2.jpg">File:Mōko Shūrai Ekotoba 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Samurai warriors face Mongols, during the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Japan" title="Mongol invasions of Japan">Mongol invasions of Japan</a>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Kamikaze_(typhoon)" title="Kamikaze (typhoon)">Kamikaze</a></i>, two storms, are said to have saved Japan from Mongol fleets.</div></div></div>
<p>This marked the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Heian_period" title="Heian period">Heian period</a> (794–1185), during which a distinctly indigenous Japanese culture emerged, noted for its <a href="/wiki/Japanese_art" title="Japanese art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_poetry" title="Japanese poetry">poetry</a> and prose. <a href="/wiki/Murasaki_Shikibu" title="Murasaki Shikibu">Lady Murasaki's</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i> and the lyrics of Japan's national anthem <i><a href="/wiki/Kimigayo" title="Kimigayo">Kimigayo</a></i> were written during this time.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism began to spread during the Heian era chiefly through two major sects, <a href="/wiki/Tendai" title="Tendai">Tendai</a> by <a href="/wiki/Saich%C5%8D" title="Saichō">Saichō</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shingon" title="Shingon" class="mw-redirect">Shingon</a> by <a href="/wiki/K%C5%ABkai" title="Kūkai">Kūkai</a>. <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land Buddhism</a> (<a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Ddo-sh%C5%AB" title="Jōdo-shū">Jōdo-shū</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C5%8Ddo_Shinsh%C5%AB" title="Jōdo Shinshū">Jōdo Shinshū</a>) greatly becomes popular in the latter half of the 11th century.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Feudal_era">Feudal era</span></h3>
<p>Japan's feudal era was characterized by the emergence and dominance of a ruling class of warriors, the <a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">samurai</a>. In 1185, following the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Taira_clan" title="Taira clan">Taira clan</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genpei_war&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genpei war (page does not exist)">Genpei war</a>, sung in the epic <a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Heike" title="The Tale of the Heike">Tale of Heike</a>, samurai <a href="/wiki/Minamoto_no_Yoritomo" title="Minamoto no Yoritomo">Minamoto no Yoritomo</a> was appointed <a href="/wiki/Shogun" title="Shogun">shogun</a> and established a base of power in <a href="/wiki/Kamakura,_Kanagawa" title="Kamakura, Kanagawa">Kamakura</a>. After his death, the <a href="/wiki/H%C5%8Dj%C5%8D_clan" title="Hōjō clan">Hōjō clan</a> came to power as regents for the shoguns. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zen (page does not exist)">Zen</a> school of Buddhism was introduced from China in the <a href="/wiki/Kamakura_period" title="Kamakura period">Kamakura period</a> (1185–1333) and became popular among the samurai class.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kamakura_shogunate" title="Kamakura shogunate">Kamakura shogunate</a> repelled <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Japan" title="Mongol invasions of Japan">Mongol invasions</a> in 1274 and 1281, but was eventually <a href="/wiki/Kenmu_Restoration" title="Kenmu Restoration">overthrown by Emperor Go-Daigo</a>. Go-Daigo was himself defeated by <a href="/wiki/Ashikaga_Takauji" title="Ashikaga Takauji">Ashikaga Takauji</a> in 1336.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%EF%BC%B3%EF%BD%81%EF%BD%8D%EF%BD%95%EF%BD%92%EF%BD%81%EF%BD%89.jpg" title="File:Ｓａｍｕｒａｉ.jpg">File:Ｓａｍｕｒａｉ.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Samurai" title="Samurai">Samurai</a> could <a href="/wiki/Kiri-sute_gomen" title="Kiri-sute gomen">kill a commoner</a> for the slightest insult and were widely feared by the Japanese population. <a href="/wiki/Edo_period" title="Edo period">Edo period</a>, 1798</div></div></div> 
<p>Ashikaga Takauji established the shogunate in Muromachi, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kyoto,_Kyoto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kyoto, Kyoto (page does not exist)">Kyoto</a>. This was the start of the <a href="/wiki/Muromachi_Period" title="Muromachi Period" class="mw-redirect">Muromachi Period</a> (1336–1573). The <a href="/wiki/Ashikaga_shogunate" title="Ashikaga shogunate">Ashikaga shogunate</a> achieved glory in the age of <a href="/wiki/Ashikaga_Yoshimitsu" title="Ashikaga Yoshimitsu">Ashikaga Yoshimitsu</a>, and the culture based on Zen Buddhism (art of <i><a href="/wiki/Miyabi" title="Miyabi">Miyabi</a></i>) prospered. This evolved to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Higashiyama_period&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Higashiyama period (page does not exist)">Higashiyama Culture</a>, and prospered until the 16th century. On the other hand, the succeeding Ashikaga shogunate failed to control the feudal warlords (<i><a href="/wiki/Daimyo" title="Daimyo">daimyo</a></i>), and a civil war (the <a href="/wiki/%C5%8Cnin_War" title="Ōnin War">Ōnin War</a>) began in 1467, opening the century-long <a href="/wiki/Sengoku_period" title="Sengoku period">Sengoku period</a> ("Warring States").<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 16th century, traders and <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">missionaries</a> from <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> reached Japan for the first time, initiating direct <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanban_trade&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanban trade (page does not exist)">commercial</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanban_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanban art (page does not exist)">cultural</a> exchange between Japan and the West. <a href="/wiki/Oda_Nobunaga" title="Oda Nobunaga">Oda Nobunaga</a> conquered many other daimyo using European technology and firearms; after he was assassinated in 1582, his successor <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyoshi" title="Toyotomi Hideyoshi">Toyotomi Hideyoshi</a> unified the nation in 1590. Hideyoshi <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_invasions_of_Korea_(1592%E2%80%931598)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598) (page does not exist)">invaded Korea twice</a>, but following defeats by Korean and <a href="/wiki/Ming_Dynasty" title="Ming Dynasty">Ming</a> Chinese forces and Hideyoshi's death, Japanese troops were withdrawn in 1598.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> This age is called <a href="/wiki/Azuchi%E2%80%93Momoyama_period" title="Azuchi–Momoyama period">Azuchi–Momoyama period</a> (1573–1603).
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Japan_map_1783.jpeg" title="File:Japan map 1783.jpeg">File:Japan map 1783.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Re-engraved map of Japan</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_Ieyasu" title="Tokugawa Ieyasu">Tokugawa Ieyasu</a> served as regent for Hideyoshi's <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyori" title="Toyotomi Hideyori">son</a> and used his position to gain political and military support. When open war broke out, he defeated rival clans in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sekigahara" title="Battle of Sekigahara">Battle of Sekigahara</a> in 1600. Ieyasu was appointed shogun in 1603 and established the <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a> at <a href="/wiki/Edo" title="Edo">Edo</a> (modern Tokyo).<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The Tokugawa shogunate enacted measures including <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Buke_shohatto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buke shohatto (page does not exist)">buke shohatto</a></i>, as a code of conduct to control the autonomous daimyo;<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> and in 1639, the isolationist <i><a href="/wiki/Sakoku" title="Sakoku">sakoku</a></i> ("closed country") policy that spanned the two and a half centuries of tenuous political unity known as the <a href="/wiki/Edo_period" title="Edo period">Edo period</a> (1603–1868).<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The study of Western sciences, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Rangaku" title="Rangaku">rangaku</a></i>, continued through contact with the Dutch enclave at <a href="/wiki/Dejima" title="Dejima">Dejima</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nagasaki" title="Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a>. The Edo period also gave rise to <i><a href="/wiki/Kokugaku" title="Kokugaku">kokugaku</a></i> ("national studies"), the study of Japan by the Japanese.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<p>On March 31, 1854, <a href="/wiki/Matthew_C._Perry" title="Matthew C. Perry">Commodore Matthew Perry</a> and the "<a href="/wiki/Black_Ships" title="Black Ships">Black Ships</a>" of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_Navy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States Navy (page does not exist)">United States Navy</a> forced the opening of Japan to the outside world with the <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_Kanagawa" title="Convention of Kanagawa">Convention of Kanagawa</a>. Subsequent similar treaties with Western countries in the <a href="/wiki/Bakumatsu" title="Bakumatsu">Bakumatsu</a> period brought economic and political crises. The resignation of the shogun led to the <a href="/wiki/Boshin_War" title="Boshin War">Boshin War</a> and the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_the_han_system" title="Abolition of the han system">centralized state</a> nominally unified under the Emperor (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meiji_Restoration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meiji Restoration (page does not exist)">Meiji Restoration</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Generals_Pyongyang_MigitaToshihide_October1894.jpg" title="File:Generals Pyongyang MigitaToshihide October1894.jpg">File:Generals Pyongyang MigitaToshihide October1894.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chinese generals surrender to the Japanese. <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">Sino-Japanese War</a> of 1894–1895.</div></div></div>
<p>Adopting Western political, judicial and military institutions, the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Japan" title="Cabinet of Japan">Cabinet</a> organized the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Privy_Council_(Japan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Privy Council (Japan) (page does not exist)">Privy Council</a>, introduced the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Constitution" title="Meiji Constitution">Meiji Constitution</a>, and assembled the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diet_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diet of Japan (page does not exist)">Imperial Diet</a>. The Meiji Restoration transformed the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> into an industrialized world power that pursued military conflict to expand its sphere of influence. After victories in the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (1894–1895) and the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a> (1904–1905), Japan gained control of Taiwan, Korea, and the southern half of <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Japan's population grew from 35 million in 1873 to 70 million in 1935.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Meiji_tenno1.jpg" title="File:Meiji tenno1.jpg">File:Meiji tenno1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Emperor_Meiji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emperor Meiji (page does not exist)">Emperor Meiji</a> (1868–1912), in whose name imperial rule was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Meiji_Restoration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Meiji Restoration (page does not exist)">restored</a> at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</a></div></div></div>
<p>The early 20th century saw a brief period of "<a href="/wiki/Taish%C5%8D_period" title="Taishō period">Taishō democracy</a>" overshadowed by increasing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expansionism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expansionism (page does not exist)">expansionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_militarism" title="Japanese militarism">militarization</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War&#160;I</a> enabled Japan, on the side of the victorious <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a>, to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_during_World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan during World War I (page does not exist)">widen its influence and territorial holdings</a>. It continued its expansionist policy by occupying <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a> in 1931; as a result of <a href="/wiki/Lytton_Report" title="Lytton Report">international condemnation of this occupation</a>, Japan resigned from the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> two years later. In 1936, Japan signed the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Comintern_Pact" title="Anti-Comintern Pact">Anti-Comintern Pact</a> with <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, and the 1940 <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">Tripartite Pact</a> made it one of the Axis Powers.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> In 1941, Japan negotiated the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_Neutrality_Pact" title="Soviet–Japanese Neutrality Pact">Soviet–Japanese Neutrality Pact</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Empire of Japan invaded other parts of China in 1937, precipitating the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> (1937–1945). The Imperial Japanese Army swiftly captured the capital <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> and conducted the <a href="/wiki/Nanking_Massacre" title="Nanking Massacre">Nanking Massacre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>  In 1940, the Empire then <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina (page does not exist)">invaded French Indochina</a>, after which the United States placed an oil embargo on Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> On December 7, 1941, Japan <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attacked the US naval base</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pearl_Harbor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pearl Harbor (page does not exist)">Pearl Harbor</a> and declared war, bringing the US into World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Soviet invasion of Manchuria">Soviet invasion of Manchuria</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (page does not exist)">atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki</a> in 1945, Japan agreed to an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Surrender_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Surrender of Japan (page does not exist)">unconditional surrender</a> on August 15.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The war cost Japan and the rest of the <a href="/wiki/Greater_East_Asia_Co-Prosperity_Sphere" title="Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere">Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere</a> millions of lives and left much of the nation's industry and infrastructure destroyed. The <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> (led by the US) repatriated millions of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_diaspora" title="Japanese diaspora">ethnic Japanese</a> from colonies and military camps throughout Asia, largely eliminating the Japanese empire and restoring the independence of its conquered territories.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The Allies also convened the <a href="/wiki/International_Military_Tribunal_for_the_Far_East" title="International Military Tribunal for the Far East">International Military Tribunal for the Far East</a> on May 3, 1946 to prosecute some Japanese leaders for <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war crimes</a>. However, the <a href="/wiki/Unit_731" title="Unit 731">bacteriological research units</a> and members of the imperial family involved in the war were exonerated from criminal prosecutions by the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Allied_Commander" title="Supreme Allied Commander">Supreme Allied Commander</a> despite calls for trials for both groups.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1947, Japan adopted a new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">constitution</a> emphasizing liberal democratic practices. The <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan" title="Occupation of Japan">Allied occupation</a> ended with the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco" title="Treaty of San Francisco">Treaty of San Francisco</a> in 1952<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> and Japan was granted membership in the United Nations in 1956. Japan later achieved <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_post-war_economic_miracle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese post-war economic miracle (page does not exist)">rapid growth</a> to become the second-largest economy in the world, until surpassed by China in 2010. This ended in the mid-1990s when Japan suffered a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_asset_price_bubble&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese asset price bubble (page does not exist)">major recession</a>. In the beginning of the 21st century, positive growth has signaled a gradual economic recovery.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> On March 11, 2011, Japan suffered the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami (page does not exist)">strongest earthquake in its recorded history</a>; this triggered the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>, one of the worst disasters in the history of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes-tsunami_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-tsunami-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Akihito_090710-1600a.jpg" title="File:Akihito 090710-1600a.jpg">File:Akihito 090710-1600a.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Akihito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akihito (page does not exist)">Emperor Akihito</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empress_Michiko" title="Empress Michiko">Empress Michiko</a></div></div></div>
<p>Japan is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> where the power of the <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">Emperor</a> is very limited. As a ceremonial figurehead, he is defined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">constitution</a> as "the symbol of the state and of the unity of the people." Power is held chiefly by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan" title="Prime Minister of Japan">Prime Minister of Japan</a> and other elected members of the Diet, while sovereignty is vested in the Japanese people.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-55">[55]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akihito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akihito (page does not exist)">Akihito</a> is the current Emperor of Japan; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crown_Prince_Naruhito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crown Prince Naruhito (page does not exist)">Naruhito, Crown Prince of Japan</a>, stands as next in line to the throne.
</p><p>Japan's legislative organ is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diet_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diet of Japan (page does not exist)">National Diet</a>, a bicameral parliament. The Diet consists of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_of_Representatives_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House of Representatives of Japan (page does not exist)">House of Representatives</a> with 480 seats, elected by popular vote every four years or when dissolved, and a <a href="/wiki/House_of_Councillors" title="House of Councillors">House of Councillors</a> of 242 seats, whose popularly elected members serve six-year terms. There is <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> for adults over 20 years of age,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> with a <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secret ballot</a> for all elected offices.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-55">[55]</a></sup> The Diet is dominated by the social liberal <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_of_Japan" title="Democratic Party of Japan">Democratic Party of Japan</a> and the conservative <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democratic_Party_(Japan)" title="Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)">Liberal Democratic Party</a> (LDP). The LDP has enjoyed near continuous electoral success since 1955, except for a brief 11 month period between 1993 and 1994, and from 2009 to 2012. It holds 294 seats in the lower house and 83 seats in the upper house.
</p><p>The Prime Minister of Japan is the head of government and is appointed by the Emperor after being designated by the Diet from among its members. The Prime Minister is the head of the Cabinet, and he appoints and dismisses the <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_State" title="Minister of State">Ministers of State</a>. Following the LDP's landslide victory in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_general_election,_2012&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese general election, 2012 (page does not exist)">2012 general election</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shinz%C5%8D_Abe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shinzō Abe (page does not exist)">Shinzō Abe</a> replaced <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yoshihiko_Noda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yoshihiko Noda (page does not exist)">Yoshihiko Noda</a> as the Prime Minister on December 26, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>  Although the Prime Minister is formally appointed by the Emperor, the Constitution of Japan explicitly requires the Emperor to appoint whoever is designated by the Diet.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_55-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically influenced by <a href="/wiki/Chinese_law" title="Chinese law">Chinese law</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Japan" title="Law of Japan">Japanese legal system</a> developed independently during the <a href="/wiki/Edo" title="Edo">Edo</a> period through texts such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kujikata_Osadamegaki" title="Kujikata Osadamegaki">Kujikata Osadamegaki</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> However, since the late 19th century the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Judicial_system_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Judicial system of Japan (page does not exist)">judicial system</a> has been largely based on the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> of Europe, notably Germany. For example, in 1896, the Japanese government established a civil code based on a draft of the German <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCrgerliches_Gesetzbuch" title="Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch">Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch</a>; with post–World War II modifications, the code remains in effect.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> Statutory law originates in Japan's legislature and has the <a href="/wiki/Rubber_stamp_(politics)" title="Rubber stamp (politics)">rubber stamp</a> of the Emperor. The Constitution requires that the Emperor promulgate legislation passed by the Diet, without specifically giving him the power to oppose legislation.<sup id="cite_ref-Constitution_55-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution-55">[55]</a></sup> Japan's court system is divided into four basic tiers: the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Japan" title="Supreme Court of Japan">Supreme Court</a> and three levels of lower courts.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> The main body of Japanese statutory law is called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Six_Codes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Six Codes (page does not exist)">Six Codes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_military">Foreign relations and military</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SM3_from_JDS_Kongo.jpg" title="File:SM3 from JDS Kongo.jpg">File:SM3 from JDS Kongo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=JDS_Kong%C5%8D_(DDG-173)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="JDS Kongō (DDG-173) (page does not exist)">JDS <i>Kongō</i> (DDG-173)</a> <a href="/wiki/Guided_missile_destroyer" title="Guided missile destroyer">guided missile destroyer</a> launching a <a href="/w/index.php?title=RIM-161_Standard_Missile_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RIM-161 Standard Missile 3 (page does not exist)">Standard Missile 3</a> <a href="/wiki/Anti-ballistic_missile" title="Anti-ballistic missile">anti-ballistic missile</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Japan is a member of the <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=ASEAN_Plus_Three&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASEAN Plus Three (page does not exist)">ASEAN Plus Three</a>", and is a participant in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia_Summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia Summit (page does not exist)">East Asia Summit</a>. Japan signed a security pact with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> in March 2007<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> and with <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> in October 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> It is the world's third largest donor of <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> after the United States and France, donating US$9.48 billion in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan has close economic and military relations with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>; the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan%E2%80%93United_States_relations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan–United States relations (page does not exist)">US-Japan security alliance</a> acts as the cornerstone of the nation's foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> A member state of the United Nations since 1956, Japan has served as a non-permanent <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a> member for a <a href="/wiki/List_of_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council#List_by_number_of_years_as_Security_Council_member" title="List of members of the United Nations Security Council">total of 20 years</a>, most recently for 2009 and 2010. It is one of the <a href="/wiki/G4_nations" title="G4 nations">G4 nations</a> seeking permanent membership in the Security Council.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan is engaged in several territorial disputes with its neighbors: with Russia over the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands_dispute" title="Kuril Islands dispute">South Kuril Islands</a>, with South Korea over the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liancourt_Rocks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liancourt Rocks (page does not exist)">Liancourt Rocks</a>, with China and Taiwan over the <a href="/wiki/Senkaku_Islands" title="Senkaku Islands">Senkaku Islands</a>, and with China over the <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">EEZ</a> around <a href="/wiki/Okinotorishima" title="Okinotorishima">Okinotorishima</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Japan also faces an ongoing dispute with <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> over the latter's <a href="/wiki/North_Korean_abductions_of_Japanese_citizens" title="North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens">abduction of Japanese citizens</a> and its <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="North Korea and weapons of mass destruction">nuclear weapons and missile program</a> (see also <a href="/wiki/Six-party_talks" title="Six-party talks">Six-party talks</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan maintains one of the largest military budgets of any country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Japan contributed non-combatant troops to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq War (page does not exist)">Iraq War</a> but subsequently withdrew its forces.<sup id="cite_ref-Iraq_deployment_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iraq_deployment-69">[69]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Maritime_Self-Defense_Force&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (page does not exist)">Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force</a> is a regular participant in <a href="/w/index.php?title=RIMPAC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RIMPAC (page does not exist)">RIMPAC</a> maritime exercises.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan's military is restricted by Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution, which renounces Japan's right to declare war or use military force in international disputes. Japan's military is governed by the Ministry of Defense, and primarily consists of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Ground_Self-Defense_Force&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (page does not exist)">Japan Ground Self-Defense Force</a> (JGSDF), the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Air_Self-Defense_Force&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Air Self-Defense Force (page does not exist)">Japan Air Self-Defense Force</a> (JASDF). The forces have been recently used in peacekeeping operations; the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Iraq_Reconstruction_and_Support_Group" title="Japanese Iraq Reconstruction and Support Group">deployment of troops to Iraq</a> marked the first overseas use of Japan's military since World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-Iraq_deployment_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iraq_deployment-69">[69]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Keidanren" title="Nippon Keidanren" class="mw-redirect">Nippon Keidanren</a> has called on the government to lift the ban on arms exports so that Japan can join multinational projects such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joint_Strike_Fighter_program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joint Strike Fighter program (page does not exist)">Joint Strike Fighter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Japan consists of forty-seven prefectures, each overseen by an elected governor, legislature and administrative bureaucracy. Each prefecture is further divided into cities, towns and villages.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> The nation is currently undergoing administrative <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merger_and_dissolution_of_municipalities_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merger and dissolution of municipalities of Japan (page does not exist)">reorganization by merging</a> many of the cities, towns and villages with each other. This process will reduce the number of sub-prefecture administrative regions and is expected to cut administrative costs.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Japan_Regions_and_Prefectures_Labelled_Map&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Japan Regions and Prefectures Labelled Map (page does not exist)">Template:Japan Regions and Prefectures Labelled Map</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Japan_topo_en.jpg" title="File:Japan topo en.jpg">File:Japan topo en.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Topographic map of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_archipelago" title="Japanese archipelago">Japanese archipelago</a></div></div></div>
<p>Japan has a total of 6,852 islands extending along the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_coast" title="Pacific coast">Pacific coast</a> of East Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The country, including all of the islands it controls, lies between latitudes 24° and 46°N, and longitudes 122° and 146°E. The main islands, from north to south, are <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaidō</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">Honshū</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">Shikoku</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ky%C5%ABsh%C5%AB&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kyūshū (page does not exist)">Kyūshū</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ryukyu_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ryukyu Islands (page does not exist)">Ryūkyū Islands</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Okinawa_Island" title="Okinawa Island">Okinawa</a>, are a chain to the south of Kyūshū. Together they are often known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Archipelago&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Archipelago (page does not exist)">Japanese Archipelago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>About 73 percent of Japan is forested, mountainous, and unsuitable for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agriculture,_forestry,_and_fishing_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agriculture, forestry, and fishing in Japan (page does not exist)">agricultural</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Manufacturing_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manufacturing in Japan (page does not exist)">industrial</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Housing_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Housing in Japan (page does not exist)">residential</a> use.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> As a result, the habitable zones, mainly located in coastal areas, have extremely high population densities. Japan is one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_population_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by population density (page does not exist)">most densely populated countries</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>The islands of Japan are located in a <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanic</a> zone on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pacific_Ring_of_Fire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pacific Ring of Fire (page does not exist)">Pacific Ring of Fire</a>. They are primarily the result of large oceanic movements occurring over hundreds of millions of years from the mid-Silurian to the Pleistocene as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subduction</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea_Plate" title="Philippine Sea Plate">Philippine Sea Plate</a> beneath the continental <a href="/wiki/Amurian_Plate" title="Amurian Plate">Amurian Plate</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Okinawa_Plate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Okinawa Plate (page does not exist)">Okinawa Plate</a> to the south, and subduction of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">Pacific Plate</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Okhotsk_Plate" title="Okhotsk Plate">Okhotsk Plate</a> to the north. Japan was originally attached to the eastern coast of the Eurasian continent. The subducting plates pulled Japan eastward, opening the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a> around 15 million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan has 108 active volcanoes. Destructive earthquakes, often resulting in <a href="/wiki/Tsunami" title="Tsunami">tsunami</a>, occur several times each century.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1923_Great_Kant%C5%8D_earthquake" title="1923 Great Kantō earthquake">1923 Tokyo earthquake</a> killed over 140,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> More recent major quakes are the 1995 <a href="/wiki/Great_Hanshin_earthquake" title="Great Hanshin earthquake">Great Hanshin earthquake</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami (page does not exist)">2011 Tōhoku earthquake</a>, a 9.0-magnitude<sup id="cite_ref-USGS9.0_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USGS9.0-82">[82]</a></sup> quake which hit Japan on March 11, 2011, and triggered a large tsunami.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes-tsunami_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-tsunami-54">[54]</a></sup> On May 24, 2012, 6.1 magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northeastern Japan. However, no tsunami was generated.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cherry_blossoms_at_Yoshinoyama_01.jpg" title="File:Cherry blossoms at Yoshinoyama 01.jpg">File:Cherry blossoms at Yoshinoyama 01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Cherry_blossom" title="Cherry blossom">Cherry blossoms</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mount_Yoshino&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mount Yoshino (page does not exist)">Mount Yoshino</a> has been the subject of many plays and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Waka_(poetry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Waka (poetry) (page does not exist)">waka poetry</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kongobuji_Koyasan07n3200.jpg" title="File:Kongobuji Koyasan07n3200.jpg">File:Kongobuji Koyasan07n3200.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Autumn maple leaves (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Momiji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Momiji (page does not exist)">momiji</a>) at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kong%C5%8Dbu-ji&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kongōbu-ji (page does not exist)">Kongōbu-ji</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mount_K%C5%8Dya" title="Mount Kōya">Mount Kōya</a>, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.</div></div></div>
<p>The climate of Japan is predominantly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temperate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temperate (page does not exist)">temperate</a>, but varies greatly from north to south. Japan's geographical features divide it into six principal climatic zones: Hokkaidō, Sea of Japan, <a href="/wiki/Central_Highland_(Japan)" title="Central Highland (Japan)">Central Highland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seto_Inland_Sea" title="Seto Inland Sea">Seto Inland Sea</a>, Pacific Ocean, and Ryūkyū Islands. The northernmost zone, Hokkaido, has a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> with long, cold winters and very warm to cool summers. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Precipitation_(meteorology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Precipitation (meteorology) (page does not exist)">Precipitation</a> is not heavy, but the islands usually develop deep snowbanks in the winter.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Sea of Japan zone on Honshū's west coast, northwest winter winds bring heavy snowfall. In the summer, the region is cooler than the Pacific area, though it sometimes experiences extremely hot temperatures because of the <a href="/wiki/Foehn_wind" title="Foehn wind">foehn wind</a>. The Central Highland has a typical inland humid continental climate, with large temperature differences between summer and winter, and between day and night; precipitation is light, though winters are usually snowy. The mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%ABgoku_region" title="Chūgoku region">Chūgoku</a> and Shikoku regions shelter the Seto Inland Sea from seasonal winds, bringing mild weather year-round.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Pacific coast features a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humid_subtropical&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humid subtropical (page does not exist)">humid subtropical</a> climate that experiences milder winters with occasional snowfall and hot, humid summers because of the southeast seasonal wind. The Ryukyu Islands have a <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropical climate</a>, with warm winters and hot summers. Precipitation is very heavy, especially during the rainy season. The generally humid, temperate climate exhibits marked seasonal variation such as the blooming of the spring cherry blossoms, the calls of the summer cicada and fall foliage colors that are celebrated in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_art" title="Japanese art">art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_literature" title="Japanese literature">literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_84-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The average winter temperature in Japan is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and the average summer temperature is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The highest temperature ever measured in Japan—<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>—was recorded on August 16, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The main <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asian_rainy_season&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asian rainy season (page does not exist)">rainy season</a> begins in early May in Okinawa, and the rain front gradually moves north until reaching Hokkaidō in late July. In most of Honshū, the rainy season begins before the middle of June and lasts about six weeks. In late summer and early autumn, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Typhoon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Typhoon (page does not exist)">typhoons</a> often bring heavy rain.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Japanese_Macaque_Fuscata_Image_367.jpg" title="File:Japanese Macaque Fuscata Image 367.jpg">File:Japanese Macaque Fuscata Image 367.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Japanese_macaque" title="Japanese macaque">Japanese macaques</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jigokudani_Monkey_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jigokudani Monkey Park (page does not exist)">Jigokudani hot spring</a> are notable for visiting the spa in the winter.</div></div></div>
<p>Japan has nine forest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ecoregions_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ecoregions in Japan (page does not exist)">ecoregions</a> which reflect the climate and geography of the islands. They range from <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">subtropical moist broadleaf forests</a> in the Ryūkyū and <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Bonin Islands</a>, to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests (page does not exist)">temperate broadleaf and mixed forests</a> in the mild climate regions of the main islands, to <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forests</a> in the cold, winter portions of the northern islands.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> Japan has over 90,000 species of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wildlife_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wildlife of Japan (page does not exist)">wildlife</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_macaque" title="Japanese macaque">Japanese macaque</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_raccoon_dog&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese raccoon dog (page does not exist)">Japanese raccoon dog</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_giant_salamander&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese giant salamander (page does not exist)">Japanese giant salamander</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> A large network of <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Japan" title="List of national parks of Japan">national parks</a> has been established to protect important areas of flora and fauna as well as thirty-seven <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ramsar_sites_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ramsar sites in Japan (page does not exist)">Ramsar wetland sites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Heritage Sites in Japan (page does not exist)">Four sites</a> have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List for their outstanding natural value.<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In the period of rapid economic growth after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, environmental policies were downplayed by the government and industrial corporations; as a result, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Four_Big_Pollution_Diseases_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Four Big Pollution Diseases of Japan (page does not exist)">environmental pollution</a> was widespread in the 1950s and 1960s. Responding to rising concern about the problem, the government introduced several environmental protection laws in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil crisis in 1973</a> also encouraged the efficient use of energy because of Japan's lack of natural resources.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> Current environmental issues include urban air pollution (<a href="/w/index.php?title=NOx&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NOx (page does not exist)">NOx</a>, suspended particulate matter, and toxics), <a href="/wiki/Waste_management" title="Waste management">waste management</a>, water <a href="/wiki/Eutrophication" title="Eutrophication">eutrophication</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nature_conservation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nature conservation (page does not exist)">nature conservation</a>, climate change, chemical management and international co-operation for conservation.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan is one of the world's leaders in the development of new environment-friendly technologies, and is ranked 26th best in the world in the 2014 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_Performance_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental Performance Index (page does not exist)">Environmental Performance Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> As a signatory of the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a>, and host of the 1997 conference which created it, Japan is under treaty obligation to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions and to take other steps to curb climate change.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_stock_exchange.jpg" title="File:Tokyo stock exchange.jpg">File:Tokyo stock exchange.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Stock_Exchange" title="Tokyo Stock Exchange">Tokyo Stock Exchange</a>, the largest stock exchange in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-fm_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fm-98">[98]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_history">Economic history</span></h3>
<p>Some of the structural features for Japan's economic growth developed in the Edo period, such as the network of transport routes, by <a href="/wiki/Kaid%C5%8D" title="Kaidō">road</a> and water, and the <a href="/wiki/Futures_contract" title="Futures contract">futures contracts</a>, banking and insurance of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Osaka_rice_brokers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Osaka rice brokers (page does not exist)">Osaka rice brokers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> During the Meiji period from 1868, Japan expanded economically with the embrace of the <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Many of today's enterprises were founded at the time, and Japan emerged as the most developed nation in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> The period of overall real economic growth from the 1960s to the 1980s has been called the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_post-war_economic_miracle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese post-war economic miracle (page does not exist)">Japanese post-war economic miracle</a>: it averaged 7.5 percent in the 1960s and 1970s, and 3.2 percent in the 1980s and early 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>Growth slowed markedly in the 1990s during what the Japanese call <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lost_Decade_(Japan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lost Decade (Japan) (page does not exist)">the Lost Decade</a>, largely because of the after-effects of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_asset_price_bubble&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese asset price bubble (page does not exist)">Japanese asset price bubble</a> and domestic policies intended to wring speculative excesses from the stock and real estate markets. Government efforts to revive economic growth met with little success and were further hampered by the <a href="/wiki/Dot-com_bubble" title="Dot-com bubble">global slowdown in 2000</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> The economy showed strong signs of recovery after 2005; GDP growth for that year was 2.8 percent, surpassing the growth rates of the US and <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> during the same period.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
