</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Japan is the third largest national economy in the world, after the United States and China, in terms of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nominal_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nominal GDP (page does not exist)">nominal GDP</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> and the fourth largest national economy in the world, after the United States, China and India, in terms of <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-6">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Japan's <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">public debt</a> was more than 200 percent of its annual gross domestic product, the second largest of any nation in the world. In August 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moody%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moody's (page does not exist)">Moody's</a> rating has cut Japan's long-term sovereign debt rating one notch from Aa3 to Aa2 inline with the size of the country's deficit and borrowing level. The large budget deficits and government debt since the 2009 global recession and followed by earthquake and tsunami in March 2011 made the rating downgrade.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" title="Service sector" class="mw-redirect">service sector</a> accounts for three quarters of the gross domestic product.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Exports">Exports</span></h3>
<p><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mof.go.jp/english/statistics/index.html">The Ministry of Finance in Japan</a>, led by Minister <a href="/wiki/Tar%C5%8D_As%C5%8D" title="Tarō Asō">Tarō Asō</a>, is responsible for maintaining <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.customs.go.jp/toukei/info/tsdl_e.htm">statistical data</a> regarding the Japanese economy.
Japan has a large industrial capacity, and is home to some of the largest and most technologically advanced producers of motor vehicles, <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Machine_tool" title="Machine tool">machine tools</a>, steel and nonferrous metals, ships, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chemical_substance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chemical substance (page does not exist)">chemical substances</a>, textiles, and <a href="/wiki/Food_processing" title="Food processing">processed foods</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agriculture,_forestry,_and_fishing_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agriculture, forestry, and fishing in Japan (page does not exist)">Agricultural businesses in Japan</a> cultivate 13 percent of Japan's land, and Japan accounts for nearly 15 percent of the global fish catch, second only to China.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> As of 2010, Japan's labor force consisted of some 65.9 million workers.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> Japan has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_unemployment_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by unemployment rate (page does not exist)">low unemployment rate</a> of around four percent. Almost one in six Japanese, or 20 million people, lived in poverty in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Housing_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Housing in Japan (page does not exist)">Housing in Japan</a> is characterized by limited land supply in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Toyota_Prius_plug-in_--_2010_DC.jpg" title="File:Toyota Prius plug-in -- 2010 DC.jpg">File:Toyota Prius plug-in -- 2010 DC.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A plug-in <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">hybrid car</a> manufactured by <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a>, one of the world's largest carmakers. Japan is the second-largest producer of automobiles in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Japan's exports amounted to US$4,210 per capita in 2005. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Japan's main export markets were China (18.88 percent), the United States (16.42 percent), South Korea (8.13 percent), Taiwan (6.27 percent) and Hong Kong (5.49 percent). Its main exports are transportation equipment, motor vehicles, electronics, electrical machinery and chemicals.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> Japan's main import markets as of 2009 were China (22.2 percent), the US (10.96 percent), Australia (6.29 percent), <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> (5.29 percent), <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> (4.12 percent), South Korea (3.98 percent) and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> (3.95 percent).<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imports">Imports</span></h3>
<p>Japan's main imports are machinery and equipment, <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a>, foodstuffs (in particular beef), chemicals, textiles and raw materials for its industries.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_111-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-111">[111]</a></sup> By market share measures, domestic markets are the least open of any <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">OECD</a> country.<sup id="cite_ref-oecd2008_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2008-112">[112]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Junichiro_Koizumi" title="Junichiro Koizumi">Junichiro Koizumi</a>'s administration began some pro-competition reforms, and foreign investment in Japan has soared.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan ranks 12th of 178 countries in the 2008 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ease_of_doing_business_index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ease of doing business index (page does not exist)">Ease of doing business index</a> and has <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_tax_revenue_as_percentage_of_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by tax revenue as percentage of GDP (page does not exist)">one of the smallest tax revenues</a> of the developed world. The Japanese variant of capitalism has many distinct features: <a href="/wiki/Keiretsu" title="Keiretsu">keiretsu</a> enterprises are influential, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Permanent_employment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Permanent employment (page does not exist)">lifetime employment</a> and seniority-based career advancement are relatively common in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_work_environment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese work environment (page does not exist)">Japanese work environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oecd2008_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2008-112">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Japanese companies are known for management methods like "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Toyota_Way&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Toyota Way (page does not exist)">The Toyota Way</a>", and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shareholder_activism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shareholder activism (page does not exist)">shareholder activism</a> is rare.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the largest enterprises in Japan include <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">Toyota</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">Nintendo</a>, <a href="/wiki/NTT_DoCoMo" title="NTT DoCoMo">NTT DoCoMo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canon_Inc." title="Canon Inc.">Canon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honda" title="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Takeda_Pharmaceutical_Company" title="Takeda Pharmaceutical Company">Takeda Pharmaceutical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panasonic_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panasonic Corporation (page does not exist)">Panasonic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toshiba" title="Toshiba">Toshiba</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sharp_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sharp Corporation (page does not exist)">Sharp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Steel" title="Nippon Steel">Nippon Steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Oil" title="Nippon Oil">Nippon Oil</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seven_%26_I_Holdings_Co.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seven &amp; I Holdings Co. (page does not exist)">Seven &amp; I Holdings Co.</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> It has some of the world's largest banks, and the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Stock_Exchange" title="Tokyo Stock Exchange">Tokyo Stock Exchange</a> (known for its <a href="/wiki/Nikkei_225" title="Nikkei 225">Nikkei 225</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=TOPIX&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TOPIX (page does not exist)">TOPIX</a> indices) stands as the second largest in the world by <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Japan was home to 326 companies from the <a href="/wiki/Forbes_Global_2000" title="Forbes Global 2000">Forbes Global 2000</a> or 16.3 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2013, it was announced that Japan would be importing <a href="/wiki/Shale" title="Shale">shale</a> <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg" title="File:Kibo PM and ELM-PS.jpg">File:Kibo PM and ELM-PS.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Experiment_Module&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Experiment Module (page does not exist)">Japanese Experiment Module</a> (Kibo) at the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Japan is a leading nation in scientific research, particularly technology, machinery and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biomedical_research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biomedical research (page does not exist)">biomedical research</a>. Nearly 700,000 researchers share a US$130 billion <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> budget, the third largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Japan is a world leader in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fundamental_research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fundamental research (page does not exist)">fundamental scientific research</a>, having produced sixteen <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel laureates</a> in either physics, chemistry or medicine,<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> three <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields medalists</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> and one <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Friedrich_Gauss_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Friedrich Gauss Prize (page does not exist)">Gauss Prize</a> laureate.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> Some of Japan's more prominent technological contributions are in the fields of electronics, automobiles, machinery, <a href="/wiki/Earthquake_engineering" title="Earthquake engineering">earthquake engineering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Industrial_robot" title="Industrial robot">industrial robotics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Optics" title="Optics">optics</a>, chemicals, <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">semiconductors</a> and metals. Japan leads the world in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robotics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robotics (page does not exist)">robotics</a> production and use, possessing more than half (402,200 of 742,500) of the world's industrial robots.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japan_Aerospace_Exploration_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (page does not exist)">Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency</a> (JAXA) is Japan's <a href="/wiki/Space_agency" title="Space agency" class="mw-redirect">space agency</a>; it conducts space, planetary, and aviation research, and leads development of rockets and satellites. It is a participant in the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Experiment_Module&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Experiment Module (page does not exist)">Japanese Experiment Module</a> (Kibo) was added to the station during <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> assembly flights in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Japan's plans in <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> include: launching a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Space_probe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Space probe (page does not exist)">space probe</a> to <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Akatsuki_(spacecraft)" title="Akatsuki (spacecraft)">Akatsuki</a></i>;<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> developing the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mercury_Magnetospheric_Orbiter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter (page does not exist)">Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter</a></i> to be launched in 2013;<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> and building a <a href="/wiki/Colonization_of_the_Moon" title="Colonization of the Moon">moon base</a> by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 14, 2007, it launched lunar explorer "<i><a href="/wiki/SELENE" title="SELENE">SELENE</a></i>" (<b>Sel</b>enological and <b>En</b>gineering <b>E</b>xplorer) on an <a href="/wiki/H-IIA" title="H-IIA">H-IIA</a> (Model H2A2022) carrier rocket from <a href="/wiki/Tanegashima_Space_Center" title="Tanegashima Space Center">Tanegashima Space Center</a>. <i>SELENE</i> is also known as <i>Kaguya</i>, after the lunar princess of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Bamboo_Cutter" title="The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter">The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-jaxa_nickname_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jaxa_nickname-131">[131]</a></sup> <i>Kaguya</i> is the largest lunar mission since the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">Apollo program</a>. Its purpose is to gather data on the <a href="/wiki/Moon#Formation" title="Moon">moon's origin and evolution</a>. It entered a lunar orbit on October 4,<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> flying at an altitude of about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The probe's mission was ended when it was deliberately crashed by JAXA into the Moon on June 11, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shinkansen_Nozomi_in_Tokyo.jpg" title="File:Shinkansen Nozomi in Tokyo.jpg">File:Shinkansen Nozomi in Tokyo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Nozomi <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">Shinkansen</a> or 'Bullet Train' at <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Station" title="Tokyo Station">Tokyo Station</a><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 46.4 percent of energy in Japan was produced from petroleum, 21.4 percent from coal, 16.7 percent from natural gas, 9.7 percent from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power in Japan (page does not exist)">nuclear power</a>, and 2.9 percent from <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>. Nuclear power produced 25.1 percent of Japan's electricity, as of 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> However, as of May 5, 2012, all of the country's nuclear power plants had been taken offline because of ongoing public opposition following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (page does not exist)">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a>, though government officials have been continuing to try to sway public opinion in favor of returning at least some of Japan's 50 nuclear reactors to service.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>  Given its heavy dependence on <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_oil_imports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by oil imports (page does not exist)">imported energy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Japan has aimed to diversify its sources and maintain high levels of energy efficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan's road spending has been extensive.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Its 1.2 million kilometers of paved road are the main means of transportation.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> A single network of high-speed, divided, limited-access <a href="/wiki/Toll_road" title="Toll road">toll roads</a> connects major cities and is operated by toll-collecting enterprises. New and used cars are inexpensive; car ownership fees and fuel levies are used to promote energy efficiency. However, at just 50 percent of all distance traveled, car usage is the lowest of all G8 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-transtatsjp_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transtatsjp-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_railway_companies_in_Japan" title="List of railway companies in Japan">Dozens of Japanese railway companies</a> compete in regional and local passenger transportation markets; major companies include seven <a href="/wiki/Japan_Railways_Group" title="Japan Railways Group">JR</a> enterprises, <a href="/wiki/Kintetsu" title="Kintetsu">Kintetsu Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seibu_Railway" title="Seibu Railway">Seibu Railway</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keio_Corporation" title="Keio Corporation">Keio Corporation</a>. Some 250 high-speed <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">Shinkansen</a> trains connect major cities and Japanese trains are known for their safety and punctuality.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Proposals for a new <a href="/w/index.php?title=JR%E2%80%93Maglev&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="JR–Maglev (page does not exist)">Maglev</a> route between Tokyo and Osaka are at an advanced stage.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> There are 173 airports in Japan; the largest domestic airport, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haneda_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haneda Airport (page does not exist)">Haneda Airport</a>, is <a href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">Asia's second-busiest airport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> The largest international gateways are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Narita_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Narita International Airport (page does not exist)">Narita International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kansai_International_Airport" title="Kansai International Airport">Kansai International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%ABbu_Centrair_International_Airport" title="Chūbu Centrair International Airport">Chūbu Centrair International Airport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nagoya_Port&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nagoya Port (page does not exist)">Nagoya Port</a> is the country's largest and busiest port, accounting for 10 percent of Japan's trade value.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg" title="File:Bjs48 02 Ainu.jpg">File:Bjs48 02 Ainu.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">Ainu</a>, an ethnic minority people from Japan</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Meiji-jingu_wedding_procession_-_P1000847.jpg" title="File:Meiji-jingu wedding procession - P1000847.jpg">File:Meiji-jingu wedding procession - P1000847.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Japanese wedding at the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Shrine" title="Meiji Shrine">Meiji Shrine</a></div></div></div>
<p>Japan's population is estimated at around 127.3 million,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> with 80% of the population living on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Honsh%C5%AB&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Honshū (page does not exist)">Honshū</a>. Japanese society is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Linguistics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linguistics (page does not exist)">linguistically</a> and culturally homogeneous,<sup id="cite_ref-MulticulturalJapan_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MulticulturalJapan-150">[150]</a></sup> composed of 98.5% ethnic Japanese,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> with small populations of foreign workers.<sup id="cite_ref-MulticulturalJapan_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MulticulturalJapan-150">[150]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_Japan" title="Koreans in Japan">Zainichi Koreans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_people_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese people in Japan (page does not exist)">Zainichi Chinese</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Filipinos_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Filipinos in Japan (page does not exist)">Filipinos</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brazilian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brazilian people (page does not exist)">Brazilians</a> mostly <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" title="Japanese Brazilian">of Japanese descent</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-nikkeijin_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nikkeijin-153">[153]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peruvian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peruvian people (page does not exist)">Peruvians</a> mostly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Peruvian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Peruvian (page does not exist)">of Japanese descent</a> are among the small minority groups in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> In 2003, there were about 134,700 non-Latin American Western and 345,500 <a href="/wiki/Latin_Americans" title="Latin Americans">Latin American</a> expatriates, 274,700 of whom were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brazilians_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brazilians in Japan (page does not exist)">Brazilians</a> (said to be primarily Japanese descendants, or <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nikkeijin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nikkeijin (page does not exist)">nikkeijin</a></i>, along with their spouses),<sup id="cite_ref-nikkeijin_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nikkeijin-153">[153]</a></sup> the largest community of Westerners.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most dominant native ethnic group is the <a href="/wiki/Yamato_people" title="Yamato people">Yamato people</a>; primary minority groups include the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">Ainu</a><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_people" title="Ryukyuan people">Ryukyuan peoples</a>, as well as social minority groups like the <i><a href="/wiki/Burakumin" title="Burakumin">burakumin</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> There are persons of mixed ancestry incorporated among the 'ethnic Japanese' or Yamato, such as those from <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">Ogasawara Archipelago</a> where roughly one-tenth of the Japanese population can have European, American, Micronesian and/or Polynesian backgrounds, with some families going back up to seven generations.<sup id="cite_ref-mccormack1999_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mccormack1999-158">[158]</a></sup> In spite of the widespread belief that Japan is ethnically homogeneous (in 2009, foreign-born non-naturalized workers made up only 1.7% of the total population),<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> also because of the absence of ethnicity and/or race statistics for Japanese nationals, at least one analysis describes Japan as a <a href="/wiki/Multiethnic_society" title="Multiethnic society" class="mw-redirect">multiethnic society</a>, for example, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Lie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Lie (page does not exist)">John Lie</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> However, this statement is refused by many sectors of Japanese society, who still tend to preserve the idea of Japan being a <a href="/wiki/Monoculturalism" title="Monoculturalism">monocultural society</a> and with this ideology of homogeneity, has traditionally rejected any need to recognize ethnic differences in Japan, even as such claims have been rejected by such ethnic minorities as the <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">Ainu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_people" title="Ryukyuan people">Ryukyuan people</a>. Former Japanese Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Tar%C5%8D_As%C5%8D" title="Tarō Asō">Tarō Asō</a> has once described Japan as being a nation of “one race, one civilization, one language and one culture”.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan has the longest overall <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth of any country in the world: 83.5 years for persons born in the period 2010–2015.<sup id="cite_ref-haaretz.com_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-haaretz.com-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Table_A.17_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Table_A.17-15">[15]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aging_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aging of Japan (page does not exist)">Japanese population is rapidly aging</a> as a result of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Post–World War II baby boom (page does not exist)">post–World War II baby boom</a> followed by a decrease in birth rates. In 2009, about 22.7 percent of the population was over 65, by 2050 almost 40 percent of the population will be aged 65 and over, as projected in December 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-handbook_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-handbook-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>The changes in demographic structure have created a number of social issues, particularly a potential decline in workforce population and increase in the cost of social security benefits like the public pension plan.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> A growing number of younger Japanese are preferring not to marry or have families.<sup id="cite_ref-Ogawa_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ogawa-164">[164]</a></sup> In 2011, Japan's population dropped for a fifth year, falling by 204,000 people to 126.24 million people.  This was the greatest decline since at least 1947, when comparable figures were first compiled.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> This decline was made worse by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami (page does not exist)">March 11 earthquake and tsunami</a> which killed nearly 16,000 people with approximately another 3,000 still listed as missing.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan's population is expected to drop to 95 million by 2050,<sup id="cite_ref-handbook_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-handbook-162">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> demographers and government planners are currently in a heated debate over how to cope with this problem.<sup id="cite_ref-Ogawa_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ogawa-164">[164]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immigration (page does not exist)">Immigration</a> and birth incentives are sometimes suggested as a solution to provide younger workers to support the nation's aging population.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> Japan accepts a steady flow of 15,000 <i>new Japanese citizens</i> by <i>naturalization</i> (帰化) per year.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">UNHCR</a>, in 2012 Japan accepted just 18 refugees for resettlement,<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> while the US took in 76,000.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>Japan <a href="/w/index.php?title=Suicide_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suicide in Japan (page does not exist)">suffers from a high suicide rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-173">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Times_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times-174">[174]</a></sup> In 2009, the number of suicides exceeded 30,000 for the twelfth straight year.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Suicide is the leading cause of death for people under 30.<sup id="cite_ref-ozawa-desilva_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ozawa-desilva-176">[176]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest cities of Japan (page does not exist)">Template:Largest cities of Japan</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg" title="File:Itsukushima torii distance.jpg">File:Itsukushima torii distance.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Torii" title="Torii">Torii</a> of <a href="/wiki/Itsukushima_Shrine" title="Itsukushima Shrine">Itsukushima Shrine</a> near <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Views_of_Japan" title="Three Views of Japan">Three Views of Japan</a> and a UNESCO World Heritage Site</div></div></div>
<p>Japan enjoys full religious freedom based on Article 20 of <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">its Constitution</a>. Upper estimates suggest that 84–96 percent of the Japanese population subscribe to <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Buddhism</a> or <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">Shinto</a>, including a large number of followers of a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretism</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shinbutsu_sh%C5%ABg%C5%8D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shinbutsu shūgō (page does not exist)">both religions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> However, these estimates are based on people <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danka_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danka system (page does not exist)">affiliated</a> with a temple, rather than the number of true believers. Other studies have suggested that only 30 percent of the population identify themselves as belonging to a religion.<sup id="cite_ref-Kisala_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kisala-178">[178]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Edwin_O._Reischauer" title="Edwin O. Reischauer">Edwin Reischauer</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marius_Jansen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marius Jansen (page does not exist)">Marius Jansen</a>, some 70–80% of the Japanese regularly tell pollsters they do not consider themselves believers in any religion.<sup id="cite_ref-ReischauerJansen215_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReischauerJansen215-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nevertheless, the level of participation remains high, especially during <a href="/wiki/Japanese_festivals" title="Japanese festivals">festivals</a> and occasions such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hatsum%C5%8Dde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hatsumōde (page does not exist)">first shrine visit</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_New_Year" title="Japanese New Year">New Year</a>. <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> from China have also influenced Japanese beliefs and customs.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Japanese streets are decorated on <a href="/wiki/Tanabata" title="Tanabata">Tanabata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Obon" title="Obon" class="mw-redirect">Obon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a>. Fewer than one percent of Japanese are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianity_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianity in Japan (page does not exist)">Christian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Other minority religions include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam in Japan (page does not exist)">Islam</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hinduism_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hinduism in Japan (page does not exist)">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, and since the mid-19th century numerous <a href="/wiki/Japanese_new_religions" title="Japanese new religions">new religious movements</a> have emerged in Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-Clarke_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clarke-182">[182]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>More than 99 percent of the population speaks Japanese as their first language.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_11-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-11">[11]</a></sup> Japanese is an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agglutinative_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agglutinative language (page does not exist)">agglutinative language</a> distinguished by a system of <a href="/wiki/Honorific_speech_in_Japanese" title="Honorific speech in Japanese">honorifics</a> reflecting the hierarchical nature of Japanese society, with verb forms and particular vocabulary indicating the relative status of speaker and listener. <a href="/wiki/Japanese_writing_system" title="Japanese writing system">Japanese writing</a> uses <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">kanji</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_character&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese character (page does not exist)">Chinese characters</a>) and two sets of <a href="/wiki/Kana" title="Kana">kana</a> (<a href="/wiki/Syllabary" title="Syllabary">syllabaries</a> based on <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">simplified Chinese characters</a>), as well as the <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_numerals" title="Arabic numerals">Arabic numerals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>Besides Japanese, the <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_languages" title="Ryukyuan languages">Ryukyuan languages</a>, also part of the <a href="/wiki/Japonic_languages" title="Japonic languages">Japonic language family</a>, are spoken in Okinawa; however, few children learn these languages.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ainu_language" title="Ainu language">Ainu language</a>, which has no proven relationship to Japanese or any other language, is <a href="/wiki/Moribund_language" title="Moribund language" class="mw-redirect">moribund</a>, with only a few elderly native speakers remaining in Hokkaido.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> Most public and private schools require students to take courses in both Japanese and <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language_education_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language education in Japan (page does not exist)">English</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ItaGiappone_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ItaGiappone-187">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG" title="File:Tokyo University Entrance Exam Results 6.JPG">File:Tokyo University Entrance Exam Results 6.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Announcement of the results of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Higher_education_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Higher education in Japan (page does not exist)">entrance examinations</a> to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">University of Tokyo</a></div></div></div>
<p>Primary schools, secondary schools and universities were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Education_in_the_Empire_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Education in the Empire of Japan (page does not exist)">introduced</a> in 1872 as a result of the Meiji Restoration.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> Since 1947, compulsory education in Japan comprises <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elementary_schools_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elementary schools in Japan (page does not exist)">elementary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan#Middle_school" title="Secondary education in Japan">middle school</a>, which together last for nine years (from age 6 to age 15). Almost all children continue their education at a three-year senior <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan" title="Secondary education in Japan">high school</a>, and, according to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Education,_Culture,_Sports,_Science_and_Technology_(Japan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Japan) (page does not exist)">MEXT</a>, as of 2005 about 75.9 percent of high school graduates attended a university, junior college, trade school, or other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Higher_education_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Higher education in Japan (page does not exist)">higher education</a> institution.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>The two top-ranking universities in Japan are the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">University of Tokyo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_University" title="Kyoto University">Kyoto University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> coordinated by the OECD currently ranks the overall knowledge and skills of Japanese 15-year-olds as sixth best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In Japan, health care is provided by national and local governments. Payment for personal medical services is offered through a universal health insurance system that provides relative equality of access, with fees set by a government committee. People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments. Since 1973, all elderly persons have been covered by government-sponsored insurance.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> Patients are free to select the physicians or facilities of their choice.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg" title="File:Kinkaku-ji 01.jpg">File:Kinkaku-ji 01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Kinkaku-ji" title="Kinkaku-ji">Kinkaku-ji</a> or 'The Temple of the Golden Pavilion' in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historic_Monuments_of_Ancient_Kyoto_(Kyoto,_Uji_and_Otsu_Cities)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto (Kyoto, Uji and Otsu Cities) (page does not exist)">Kyoto</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Special_Places_of_Scenic_Beauty,_Special_Historic_Sites_and_Special_Natural_Monuments&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Special Places of Scenic Beauty, Special Historic Sites and Special Natural Monuments (page does not exist)">Special Historic Site, Special Place of Scenic Beauty</a>, and UNESCO World Heritage Site; its torching by a monk in 1950 is the subject of a <a href="/wiki/The_Temple_of_the_Golden_Pavilion" title="The Temple of the Golden Pavilion">novel</a> by <a href="/wiki/Yukio_Mishima" title="Yukio Mishima">Mishima</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Japanese culture has evolved greatly from its origins. Contemporary culture combines influences from Asia, Europe and North America. Traditional Japanese arts include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_handicrafts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese handicrafts (page does not exist)">crafts</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Japanese_pottery_and_porcelain" title="Japanese pottery and porcelain">ceramics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kimono" title="Kimono">textiles</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_lacquerware&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese lacquerware (page does not exist)">lacquerware</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_sword" title="Japanese sword">swords</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dolls" title="Japanese traditional dolls">dolls</a>; performances of <a href="/wiki/Bunraku" title="Bunraku">bunraku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kabuki" title="Kabuki">kabuki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">noh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dance" title="Japanese traditional dance">dance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rakugo" title="Rakugo">rakugo</a>; and other practices, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony" title="Japanese tea ceremony">tea ceremony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ikebana" title="Ikebana">ikebana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_martial_arts" title="Japanese martial arts">martial arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_calligraphy" title="Japanese calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Origami" title="Origami">origami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Onsen" title="Onsen">onsen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geisha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geisha (page does not exist)">Geisha</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_games" title="List of Japanese games">games</a>. Japan has a developed system for the protection and promotion of both tangible and intangible <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cultural_Properties_of_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cultural Properties of Japan (page does not exist)">Cultural Properties</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" title="National Treasures of Japan">National Treasures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Heritage Sites in Japan (page does not exist)">Sixteen sites</a> have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List, twelve of which are of cultural significance.<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <a href="/wiki/Ise_Grand_Shrine" title="Ise Grand Shrine">Shrines of Ise</a> have been celebrated as the prototype of Japanese architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> Largely of wood, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Minka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Minka (page does not exist)">traditional housing</a> and many <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_Buddhist_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese Buddhist architecture (page does not exist)">temple buildings</a> see the use of <a href="/wiki/Tatami" title="Tatami">tatami</a> mats and <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dji" title="Shōji">sliding doors</a> that break down the distinction between rooms and indoor and outdoor space.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_sculpture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese sculpture (page does not exist)">Japanese sculpture</a>, largely of wood, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_painting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese painting (page does not exist)">Japanese painting</a> are among the oldest of the Japanese arts, with early figurative paintings dating back to at least 300 BC. The history of Japanese painting exhibits synthesis and competition between native <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_aesthetics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese aesthetics (page does not exist)">Japanese aesthetics</a> and adaptation of imported ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-198">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>The interaction between Japanese and European art has been significant: for example <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">ukiyo-e</a> prints, which began to be exported in the 19th century in the movement known as <a href="/wiki/Japonism" title="Japonism">Japonism</a>, had a significant influence on the development of modern art in the West, most notably on <a href="/wiki/Post-Impressionism" title="Post-Impressionism">post-Impressionism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-198">[198]</a></sup> Famous ukiyo-e artists include <a href="/wiki/Hokusai" title="Hokusai">Hokusai</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hiroshige&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hiroshige (page does not exist)">Hiroshige</a>. The fusion of traditional <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_printing" title="Woodblock printing">woodblock printing</a> and Western art led to the creation of <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">manga</a>, a comic book format that is now popular within and outside Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> Manga-influenced animation for television and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Japan" title="Cinema of Japan">film</a> is called <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">anime</a>. Japanese-made <a href="/wiki/Video_game_console" title="Video game console">video game consoles</a> have been popular since the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Japanese music is eclectic and diverse. Many <a href="/w/index.php?title=Traditional_Japanese_musical_instruments&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Traditional Japanese musical instruments (page does not exist)">instruments</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Koto_(instrument)" title="Koto (instrument)">koto</a>, were introduced in the 9th and 10th centuries. The accompanied <a href="/wiki/Recitative" title="Recitative">recitative</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">Noh</a> drama dates from the 14th century and the popular <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan#Folk_music" title="Music of Japan">folk music</a>, with the guitar-like <a href="/wiki/Shamisen" title="Shamisen">shamisen</a>, from the sixteenth.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Western classical music, introduced in the late 19th century, now forms an integral part of Japanese culture. The imperial court ensemble <a href="/wiki/Gagaku" title="Gagaku">Gagaku</a> has influenced the work of some <a href="/wiki/20th-century_classical_music" title="20th-century classical music">modern</a> Western composers.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>Notable classical composers from Japan include <a href="/wiki/Toru_Takemitsu" title="Toru Takemitsu">Toru Takemitsu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rentar%C5%8D_Taki" title="Rentarō Taki">Rentarō Taki</a>. Popular music in post-war Japan has been heavily influenced by American and European trends, which has led to the evolution of <a href="/wiki/J-pop" title="J-pop">J-pop</a>, or Japanese popular music.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">Karaoke</a> is the most widely practiced cultural activity in Japan. A 1993 survey by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agency_for_Cultural_Affairs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agency for Cultural Affairs (page does not exist)">Cultural Affairs Agency</a> found that more Japanese had sung karaoke that year than had participated in traditional pursuits such as flower arranging (ikebana) or tea ceremonies.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg" title="File:Genji emaki 01003 001.jpg">File:Genji emaki 01003 001.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">12th-century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genji_Monogatari_Emaki&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genji Monogatari Emaki (page does not exist)">illustrated handscroll</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i>, a <a href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" title="National Treasures of Japan">National Treasure</a></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest works of Japanese literature include the <i><a href="/wiki/Kojiki" title="Kojiki">Kojiki</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Nihon_Shoki" title="Nihon Shoki">Nihon Shoki</a></i> chronicles and the <i><a href="/wiki/Man%27y%C5%8Dsh%C5%AB" title="Man'yōshū">Man'yōshū</a></i> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_poetry_anthologies" title="List of Japanese poetry anthologies">poetry anthology</a>, all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> In the early Heian period, the system of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phonogram_(linguistics)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phonogram (linguistics) (page does not exist)">phonograms</a> known as <i>kana</i> (<a href="/wiki/Hiragana" title="Hiragana">Hiragana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">Katakana</a>) was developed. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Bamboo_Cutter" title="The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter">The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter</a></i> is considered the oldest Japanese narrative.<sup id="cite_ref-ispmsu_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ispmsu-207">[207]</a></sup> An account of Heian court life is given in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Pillow_Book" title="The Pillow Book">The Pillow Book</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Sei_Sh%C5%8Dnagon" title="Sei Shōnagon">Sei Shōnagon</a>, while <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">The Tale of Genji</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Murasaki_Shikibu" title="Murasaki Shikibu">Murasaki Shikibu</a> is often described as the world's first novel.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Edo period, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ch%C5%8Dnin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chōnin (page does not exist)">chōnin</a> ("townspeople") overtook the samurai aristocracy as producers and consumers of literature. The popularity of the works of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saikaku&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saikaku (page does not exist)">Saikaku</a>, for example, reveals this change in readership and authorship, while <a href="/wiki/Matsuo_Bash%C5%8D" title="Matsuo Bashō">Bashō</a> revivified the poetic tradition of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kokinsh%C5%AB&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kokinshū (page does not exist)">Kokinshū</a> with his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haikai&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haikai (page does not exist)">haikai</a> (<a href="/wiki/Haiku" title="Haiku">haiku</a>) and wrote the poetic travelogue <i><a href="/wiki/Oku_no_Hosomichi" title="Oku no Hosomichi">Oku no Hosomichi</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The Meiji era saw the decline of traditional literary forms as Japanese literature integrated Western influences. <a href="/wiki/Natsume_S%C5%8Dseki" title="Natsume Sōseki">Natsume Sōseki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mori_%C5%8Cgai" title="Mori Ōgai">Mori Ōgai</a> were the first "modern" novelists of Japan, followed by <a href="/wiki/Ry%C5%ABnosuke_Akutagawa" title="Ryūnosuke Akutagawa">Ryūnosuke Akutagawa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jun%27ichir%C5%8D_Tanizaki" title="Jun'ichirō Tanizaki">Jun'ichirō Tanizaki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yukio_Mishima" title="Yukio Mishima">Yukio Mishima</a> and, more recently, <a href="/wiki/Haruki_Murakami" title="Haruki Murakami">Haruki Murakami</a>. Japan has two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Literature (page does not exist)">Nobel Prize-winning</a> authors—<a href="/wiki/Yasunari_Kawabata" title="Yasunari Kawabata">Yasunari Kawabata</a> (1968) and <a href="/wiki/Kenzabur%C5%8D_%C5%8Ce" title="Kenzaburō Ōe">Kenzaburō Ōe</a> (1994).<sup id="cite_ref-ispmsu_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ispmsu-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan,_Kyoto.jpg" title="File:Breakfast at Tamahan Ryokan, Kyoto.jpg">File:Breakfast at Tamahan Ryokan, Kyoto.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Breakfast at a <a href="/wiki/Ryokan_(Japanese_inn)" title="Ryokan (Japanese inn)">ryokan</a> or inn</div></div></div>
<p>Japanese cuisine is based on combining <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple foods</a>, typically <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_rice&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese rice (page does not exist)">Japanese rice</a> or <a href="/wiki/Japanese_noodles" title="Japanese noodles">noodles</a>, with a soup and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Okazu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Okazu (page does not exist)">okazu</a></i> — dishes made from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish (food) (page does not exist)">fish</a>, vegetable, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a> and the like – to add flavor to the staple food. In the early modern era ingredients such as red meats that had previously not been widely used in Japan were introduced. Japanese cuisine is known for its emphasis on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seasonal_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seasonal food (page does not exist)">seasonality of food</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> quality of ingredients and presentation. Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Japanese_regional_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Japanese regional cuisine (page does not exist)">regional specialties</a> that use traditional recipes and local ingredients. The <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin Guide</a> has awarded Japanese cities more Michelin stars than the rest of the world combined.<sup id="cite_ref-michelin20101124_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-michelin20101124-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sumo_ceremony.jpg" title="File:Sumo ceremony.jpg">File:Sumo ceremony.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">Sumo</a> wrestlers form around the referee during the ring-entering ceremony</div></div></div>
<p>Traditionally, <a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">sumo</a> is considered Japan's national sport.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_martial_arts" title="Japanese martial arts">Japanese martial arts</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">judo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karate" title="Karate">karate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kendo" title="Kendo">kendo</a> are also widely practiced and enjoyed by spectators in the country. After the Meiji Restoration, many Western sports were introduced in Japan and began to spread through the education system.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> Japan hosted the Summer Olympics in <a href="/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics" title="1964 Summer Olympics">Tokyo in 1964</a>. Japan has hosted the Winter Olympics twice: <a href="/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics" title="1972 Winter Olympics">Sapporo in 1972</a> and <a href="/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics" title="1998 Winter Olympics">Nagano in 1998</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> Tokyo will host the <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a>, making Tokyo the first Asian city to host the Olympics twice.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Japan is the most successful Asian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rugby_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rugby Union (page does not exist)">Rugby Union</a> country, winning the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_Five_Nations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian Five Nations (page does not exist)">Asian Five Nations</a> a record 6 times and winning the newly formed <a href="/w/index.php?title=IRB_Pacific_Nations_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IRB Pacific Nations Cup (page does not exist)">IRB Pacific Nations Cup</a> in 2011. Japan will host the 2019 IRB <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">Rugby World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Baseball_in_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baseball in Japan (page does not exist)">Baseball</a> is currently the most popular spectator sport in the country. Japan's top professional league, <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Professional_Baseball" title="Nippon Professional Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a>, was established in 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> Since the establishment of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=J._League&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="J. League (page does not exist)">Japan Professional Football League</a> in 1992, association football has also gained a wide following.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> Japan was a venue of the <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Cup_(football)" title="Intercontinental Cup (football)">Intercontinental Cup</a> from 1981 to 2004 and co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a> with South Korea.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup> Japan has one of the most successful football teams in Asia, winning the <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">Asian Cup</a> four times.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> Also, Japan recently won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 FIFA Women's World Cup (page does not exist)">FIFA Women's World Cup</a> in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> Golf is also popular in Japan,<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> as are forms of auto racing like the <a href="/wiki/Super_GT" title="Super GT">Super GT</a> series and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_Nippon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Formula Nippon (page does not exist)">Formula Nippon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> The country has produced one <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">NBA</a> player, <a href="/wiki/Yuta_Tabuse" title="Yuta Tabuse">Yuta Tabuse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-consulteny_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-consulteny-225">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refbegin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refbegin (page does not exist)">Template:Refbegin</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> Flath, <i>The Japanese Economy</i>, Oxford University Press, 2000 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0198775032" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-19-877503-2</a>)
</li>
<li> Henshall, <i>A History of Japan</i>, Palgrave Macmillan, 2001 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0312233701" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-312-23370-1</a>)
</li>
<li> Iwabuchi, <i>Recentering Globalization: Popular Culture and Japanese Transnationalism</i>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Duke_University_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duke University Press (page does not exist)">Duke University Press</a>, 2002 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0822328917" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8223-2891-7</a>)
</li>
<li> Jansen, <i>The Making of Modern Japan</i>, Belknap, 2000 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0674003349" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-674-00334-9</a>)
</li>
<li> Kato et al., <i>A History of Japanese Literature: From the Man'Yoshu to Modern Times</i>, Japan Library, 1997 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1873410484" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-873410-48-4</a>)
</li>
<li> Samuels, <i>Securing Japan: Tokyo's Grand Strategy and the Future of East Asia</i>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cornell_University_Press&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cornell University Press (page does not exist)">Cornell University Press</a>, 2008 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0801474906" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8014-7490-6</a>)
</li>
<li> Silverberg, <i>Erotic Grotesque Nonsense: The Mass Culture of Japanese Modern Times</i>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_California_Press" title="University of California Press">University of California Press</a>, 2007 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0520222733" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-520-22273-3</a>)
</li>
<li> Sugimoto et al., <i>An Introduction to Japanese Society</i>, Cambridge University Press, 2003 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0521529255" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-521-52925-5</a>)
</li>
<li> Varley, <i>Japanese Culture</i>, University of Hawaii Press, 2000 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0824821521" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8248-2152-1</a>)
</li>
</ul>
